data.title: [SCSS] Incorrect tab indentation when color preview is present
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version:
![vscode-version](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1855505/30512071-45050198-9ade-11e7-87e0-d7c66874c2d2.PNG)

- OS Version:
Windows 10 Pro
Version 1703
OS Build 15063.608
System Type: x64

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create a `.scss` file and add something like this:
```scss
.parent {
  color: #f00;

  .child {
    color: #f0f;
    whatever: whatever;
  }
}
```
**Note** Tabs must be used to indent the rules above.

![indentation-issue](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1855505/30512068-2cf89196-9ade-11e7-8d69-85b4e8d8e484.PNG)



<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: [debug] Source.adapterData is not preserved across debug sessions
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.16.1
- OS Version: All

The `StackFrame.source.adapterData` attribute that adapter sends to the client, does not round-trip to `SetBreakpointsArguments.source.adapterData` across debug sessions. However, protocol documentation [states that it should be preserved](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-debugadapter-node/blob/aff795a5b5b8b92ccb960390e8c96f90dd9b4a43/protocol/src/debugProtocol.ts#L1189) (or at least that's how I read it).

data.title: [Linux] KDE's menubar button does not work

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.16.1
- OS Version: Archlinux
- Desktop Environment: KDE Plasma 5.10.5

Steps to Reproduce:

1. In Plasma settings go Widget Style -> Fine tuning -> Menubar: Titlebar button :
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19470159/30510512-6f1c997e-9ace-11e7-8f3b-814c7ced4bd8.png)
2. Add this `Application menu` to window decoration: Widget Style -> Window decorations -> Buttons:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19470159/30510536-dcc0f9d4-9ace-11e7-9664-860ee4354fee.png)
3. Open any KDE app, and see that menu is gone and new button appeared:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19470159/30510560-2c68b67a-9acf-11e7-9f21-4e209ed928ba.png)
4. Open Visual Studio Code app, and check the menus:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19470159/30510568-5f50f200-9acf-11e7-8131-c258148a4b89.png)

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

### Expected behavior: 
menubar should disappear, and button should work.
### Actual behaior:
Menu is still there and button do nothing.

As electron supports KDE's global menus (or at least supported to draw them in previous versions) i'd expect them to work. But since fix of the electrons high CPU usage bug, menus are not working at all in VS Code.

data.title: Allow move viewport of documents move horizontally when dragging minimap
data.body:
Currently we can only drag the control box in minimap vertically, and it is equivalent to dragging the vertical scroll bar.
It would be convenient if we can drag it horizontally, say when we hold the `shift` key to emulate dragging the horizontal bar.

// Place your settings in this file to overwrite the default settings
{
    "puglint.enable": true,
    "typescript.check.tscVersion": false,
    "editor.formatOnSave": false,
    "editor.trimAutoWhitespace": false,
    "files.trimTrailingWhitespace": false,

    "[markdown]": {
        "files.trimTrailingWhitespace": false

}

2. Type another line 
3. Save the file. Ctrl - S

Trailing spaces are removed from line 1. In Markdown trailing spaces are semantically significant.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->

data.title: Implement privacy mode
data.body:
There should be a configurable privacy flag preventing Visual Studio Code from making any outbound connections similar to macOS firewall stealth mode. This would be useful to prevent someone with access to github operations data or an administrator of github accounts from tracking you.

Visual Studio Code immediately on launch makes various outbound tcp connections over https to Microsoft Corporation

Some Visual Studio Code out-of-the-box behavior has been seen to contact github every 3 minutes

- VSCode Version: 1.16.0
- OS Version: Linux

data.title: double-clicking on a word in peek view closes peek view
data.body:
Normally, double-clicking on a word selects the word. In "peek view" the behavior is different; it closes the window. Since double-clicking is a common editing operation, this makes it harder to edit code within peek view; you have to remember never to double-click a word.

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Right-click on a Go symbol and select "Find All References"
2. In the code in the peek view window, double-click on any word.

Expected: the word should be highlighted and the quick view should remain open, allowing you to edit the word.
Actual: the quick view window closes, losing context.

Reproduces without extensions: No
(Requires Go plugin for "Show References"; I'd guess other languages would work, though?)

Workaround: in preferences, set "editor.stablePeek" to true. However, this does too much, because clicking outside the peek view doesn't close it.

- VSCode Version: Code 1.16.1 (27492b6bf3acb0775d82d2f87b25a93490673c6d, 2017-09-14T16:24:39.530Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 15.6.0
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
python|don|0.7.0
Go|luk|0.6.65
---

data.title: opening files - issue - feature request
data.body:
I think sometimes, if you don't change a file, and click on the other one which is in a different folder is pretty annoying. The file you have opened (looked for 3 minutes) just suddenly disappears.

1, It would be very handy, if the "Open editors" might not be sync with the opened files in the editor.
(so you haven't hundreds of files opened), but my file won't be disappeared.

2, The second thing is, it would be nice, if the "open editors" would be structured. (so if you opened more than one file from the same folder than it shows a tree list with the directory name - only the last directory - so not a whole structure) and show one file per folder, if you haven't changed the file,
but if you  have clicked again from the open editors, open the other file also.

It would be tricky, but very handy and nice feature.

data.title: wrong vertical cursor movement when text wraps around

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
It seems like cursor movement is getting confused by text that wraps around

- VSCode Version: 1.16.0
- OS Version: macOS Sierra 10.12.6

Steps to Reproduce:

1) When doing movements from a line that is visually wrap'd around.
2) Press arrow down.
3) The cursor lands on the wrap'd around part of the line, instead of the 2nd line.

This is especially annoying when doing actions with multiple cursors that are working on the same sort of text where movements and edits should lead to equivalent results. In this example, I'm trying to reach the `panic(...)` line on multiple cursors, from the same "logical" location on 5 cursors. The bottom line is wrapping around and fails to land on the same spot than the 4 first ones. If I were to start editing the top line with belief that my cursors are all doing the same thing, I would end up with some weird results.

![screenflow](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1189716/30505677-31055fca-9a44-11e7-8997-7be8880d6a00.gif)

data.title: High CPU Usage (Render Processes)
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.16.1 (2017-09-14 - Shell: 1.7.3 - Renderer: 58.0.3029.110 - Node: 7.9.0 - Architecture ia32)
- OS Version: Windows Server 2012 R2 Datacenter w/GUI

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install latest version of VS Code (32bit or 64bit)
2. Run it.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

The rendering processes will each take up ~40% CPU just idling. During startup it will max the CPU the entire time starting, it takes upto 2 minutes for the UI to finally show. After that it keeps the CPU pinned at 60-100% usage doing literally nothing.

Server is a fresh install of 2k12 R2 and VSCode is a fresh install with no extensions. 
Happens on both 32bit and 64bit builds.

data.title: [json] Markdown in hovers (descriptions from schema)

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body: I have generated JSON schema which has lots of long markdown descriptions. Currently VS Code displays descriptions from schema as plain text. It would great if schema could somehow indicate that descriptions use markdown and VS Code would render it properly.

data.title: Current function name as a launch variable

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Out of all the variables I see in the launch configuration, I'm surprised there isn't one that puts in either the name of the function/method that the cursor is at, or the contents of the editor's selected text. Use case being, I use launch.json in my PHP-based project to run PHPUnit in debug mode. I can currently launch specific test files, but I can't narrow it down to a single test function. I'm aware of the PHPUnit extension, and that's great for running specific tests, but I'd rather not mess with my environment variables to do debugging and rely on other team members to be able to do it as well.

This may be a niche case, but maybe this could be useful for other cases?

data.title: Online profile to backup your preferences and extensions
data.body:
One functionality which is missing throughout all code editors is the ability to backup / restore your preferences and extensions on different devices. 

It would be really helpful If users would have some kind of "vCode account" in which they could log into, and back up their preferences and extensions, and maybe also through a sync functionality do this automatically.

I am basically describing the standard sync functionality that Chrome and Firefox have. This would save sooo much time since you could switch devices and sync your editor's configuration with your last synced one, you'd have an up and running dev environment in minutes.

data.title: Improve search aria label generation performance
data.body: When using search, if a matched line is really long (i.e. from a minified file), the UI freezes briefly because of a call to `strings.lcut()` which internally calls `split(/\b/)`. This change removes the call with no change to behavior.

data.title: [html] support script type=module
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.16.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 ( Creators Update )

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create new file & save it as .html
2. Open file in VSCode and add some content like so:
```
<script type="module">
'line1';
'line2';
"any multiline content: functions 'n stuff...";
</script>
```
3. Right click on the editor and select `Format Document` from the context menu
4. You should get some like this:
```
<script type="module">
  'line1'; 'line2'; "any multiline content: functions 'n stuff...";
</script>
```
5. As you can see, auto-formatter puts everything on one line :/

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: [html] auto close triggers on undo/redo and breaks undo/redo history

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body: - VSCode Version: 1.16.1 - OS Version: Windows 8.1 Steps to Reproduce: 1. In a html file, type (not copy) `test` 2. Undo to before step 1 3. Redo Now you cannot redo the typing of `test` or any edits after that point, as the auto close overwrote the undo/redo history. Alternate steps: 1. Delete an opening tag not immediately followed by its closing tag; e.g. delete the `` of `test` 2. Undo your deletion Reproduces without extensions: Yes Expected behavior: VSCode does not perform any new automatic formatting on undo/redo.

data.title: Terminal missing scrollbar
data.body:
The terminal scrollbar doesn't appear when scrolling, only when I hover directly over it

![sep-15-2017 11-04-56](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/323878/30496908-c082d9a0-9a05-11e7-81ff-d5ad01388857.gif)
